ML for Characterization and Processing
Lecture 9 : Inverse Problems in Processing

Prof. Dr. Philipp Pelz

FAU Erlangen-Nürnberg

Institute of Micro- and Nanostructure Research

Welcome

Week 9 — Inverse Problems in Processing

Goals for today:

  • Understand forward vs inverse problems
  • Learn ML-guided process maps (AM + metallurgy)
  • See why naïve regression fails
  • Explore physics-informed ML
  • Learn practical workflows for inverse process design

Outline

  1. What is an inverse problem?
  2. ML-guided process maps
  3. Naïve regression pitfalls
  4. Physics-informed ML
  5. Practical workflows
  6. Summary

1. What Is an Inverse Problem?

Forward problem (last week):
process → structure

Inverse problem:
desired structure → feasible process

Examples:

  • Grain size target → heat-treatment recipe
  • Porosity target in AM → power/speed window
  • Bainite target → cooling curve
  • Densification target → SPS T–P–t profile

Inverse problems are:

  • Ill-posed
  • Non-unique
  • Noisy
  • Physics-constrained

ML alone is not enough.

Structure Is Not Deterministic

Same processing ≠ same structure:

  • Variability in powder, temperature, atmosphere
  • Machine drift
  • Operator influence
  • Stochastic nucleation

Need probabilistic models + physics constraints.

2. ML-Guided Process Maps

Process maps express:

  • Operating window
  • Regime boundaries
  • Regions of defects
  • Stability and feasibility

ML helps approximate these maps from sparse data.

AM Example: Laser Power vs Scan Speed

Map axes:

  • X: scan speed
  • Y: laser power

Regions:

  • Keyholing
  • Balling
  • Lack-of-fusion
  • Stable melt pool

ML can learn:

  • Regime boundaries
  • Probability of defect formation
  • Optimal window with uncertainty

Metallurgical Analogy: TTT / CCT Diagrams

TTT/CCT link:

  • Temperature
  • Time / cooling rate
  • Phase fractions

ML can:

  • Interpolate sparse TTT data
  • Estimate CCT boundaries
  • Predict transformations for new alloys
  • Extend diagrams beyond available experiments

Process maps in metallurgy ↔︎ process maps in AM.

Other Domains: SPS and Hot Rolling

SPS:

  • Temperature vs pressure vs time
  • Densification windows

Rolling:

  • T vs strain-rate vs strain
  • Grain refinement map

All share the map-based inverse perspective.

3. Why Naïve Regression Fails

Non-uniqueness

Many process conditions → same structure.
Regression returns arbitrary choices.

Extrapolation danger

ML smooths sharp regime boundaries → unphysical predictions.

Sparse & biased data

Measurements cluster in safe regions.
ML inherits these biases.

No physics

Naïve ML may propose:

  • Impossible cooling rates
  • Unusable laser powers
  • Negative porosity
  • Invalid phase fractions

We need physics-informed ML.

4. Physics-Informed ML

Physics-informed ML integrates:

  • Thermodynamics
  • Kinetics
  • Diffusion constraints
  • Energy balance
  • Known boundaries
  • Domain knowledge

This turns the inverse problem into a constrained exploration.

Physics-Informed Methods

Physics-informed losses

Penalize violation of physical laws.

Physics-informed kernels

GP kernels encode diffusion, periodicity, smoothness.

Hard physical constraints

Limit search to feasible operating conditions.

Hybrid models

ML + simulation:

  • ML learns corrections
  • ML accelerates slow solvers
  • ML models residuals of physics equations

Examples

AM melt pool

Energy balance constraints
→ ML predicts feasible laser/speed regions only.

Heat treatment

Transformation kinetics (Avrami)
→ ML refines but cannot violate phase evolution rules.

SPS

Densification must be monotonic
→ ML constrained in output space.

TTT/CCT

Phase evolution cannot reverse
→ ML restricted by monotonicity.

Physics-Informed Inverse Search

Workflow:

  1. ML approximates process → structure
  2. Physics provides feasibility constraints
  3. Search only feasible region
  4. Return physically plausible process parameters

This avoids unphysical inverse solutions.

5. Practical Workflows

Multi-objective inverse optimization

Example: AM must balance:

  • Porosity
  • Melt pool stability
  • Build rate
  • Energy efficiency

ML finds candidate zones → physics filters them.

Gaussian Process–Based Inverse Modeling

GP gives:

  • Mean
  • Uncertainty
  • Smooth function behavior
  • Acquisition functions for exploration

Use GP to:

  • Explore uncertain regions
  • Identify optimum with confidence bounds
  • Run Bayesian optimization for process tuning

PYTHONHERE

Student Mindset

“When designing a process, ML does not give one answer — it gives a distribution, feasible regions, and confidence.”

6. Summary

Key insights:

  • Inverse problems ask: “Which processing route yields the target structure?”
  • ML-guided process maps unify AM and metallurgy
  • Naïve regression is unsafe for inverse tasks
  • Physics-informed ML respects constraints and kinetics
  • Hybrid ML–physics approaches are the future of process design
  • Inverse maps + uncertainty = actionable materials engineering
